Uses of Package
org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver

Packages that use org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver
org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver Provides the classes to create a TCP / UDP socket server that communicates using custom serialized Java messages objects. 
org.codemonkey.swiftworldserver Provides the classes to create a World Server, an extension of the Request Socket Server. 
 

Classes in org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver used by org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver
ClientContext
          Contains all session data concerning a given client.
ClientEndpoint
          Abstraction of the client socket.
ClientEndpointUDP
          Client endpoint that handles UDP traffic and maintains a list of known and new datagram messages.
ClientHandler
          Worker thread for the server that is dedicated to a single client.
ClientMessageToServer
          Defines a base for decodable and executable message types.
ServerEndpoint
          Abstraction of the server socket.
ServerEndpointUDP
          Wrapper that adds TCP like client handling to the UDP DatagramSocket.
ServerMessageToClient
          Provides a default DatagramEncoder implementation that returns an empty string.
ServerType
          Defines the type of server, ServerType.UDP or ServerType.TCP.
SwiftSocketServer
          A low level message server that mediates messages from and to clients and the server in the form of 'datagrams' (custom serialized messages identified by a unique signature).
UnknownMessageException
          Exception type thrown when a client-to-server message was not recognized by its identifier.
 

Classes in org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver used by org.codemonkey.swiftworldserver
ClientMessageToServer
          Defines a base for decodable and executable message types.
ServerMessageToClient
          Provides a default DatagramEncoder implementation that returns an empty string.
ServerType
          Defines the type of server, ServerType.UDP or ServerType.TCP.
SwiftSocketServer
          A low level message server that mediates messages from and to clients and the server in the form of 'datagrams' (custom serialized messages identified by a unique signature).
